section.title: Present Simple and Present Continuous
section.sectiontitle: Use the Present Simple for habits/routines, things that are always true/permanent and describing a state.
section.text1: Example: Seung-Ah starts work at eight o'clock.
section.sectiontitle2: Use the Present Continuous for things that are happening now, at this precise moment and temporary situations that are happening around now.
section.text3a: Jade is having a shower. (NOT: Jade has a shower.)
section.text4a: I am learning Spanish for my job. (NOT: I learn Spanish for my job.)

section.title: Present Simple and Present Continuous
section.sectiontitle: The following verbs are not often used in the continuous form: like, love, hate, have(possess), need, want, hope, prefer, find, understand, remember, know, think, realise, believe, seem, depend, suppose, mean, see, hear, smell, taste.
section.text1a:
I like eating olives. √<
(NOT: I'm liking eating olives.)
section.text2a:
I don't think this is right.
(NOT: I'm not thinking this is right.)
section.sectiontitle2: Some verbs are used in the Present Simple and Present Continuous, but their meaning changes, e.g. have.
section.text3: For an action or an experience, have can be used in the continuous.
section.text3a: We're having a wonderful holiday.
section.text4:
For possession, use have/has.
(NOT: We're having many friends.)
